info.title: GraphHopper Directions API
info.description: You use the GraphHopper Directions API to add route planning, navigation and route optimization to your software. E.g. the Routing API has turn instructions and elevation data and the Route Optimization API solves your logistic problems and supports various constraints like time window and capacity restrictions. Also it is possible to get all distances between all locations with our fast Matrix API.

get.description: The GraphHopper Routing API allows to calculate route and implement navigation via the turn instructions

parameters.name: point
parameters.description: Specify multiple points for which the route should be calculated. The order is important. Specify at least two points.

parameters.name: locale
parameters.description: The locale of the resulting turn instructions. E.g. `pt_PT` for Portuguese or `de` for German

parameters.name: instructions
parameters.description: If instruction should be calculated and returned

parameters.name: vehicle
parameters.description: The vehicle for which the route should be calculated. Other vehicles are foot, small_truck, ...

parameters.name: elevation
parameters.description: If `true` a third dimension - the elevation - is included in the polyline or in the GeoJson. If enabled you have to use a modified version of the decoding method or set points_encoded to `false`. See the points_encoded attribute for more details. Additionally a request can fail if the vehicle does not support elevation. See the features object for every vehicle.

parameters.name: points_encoded
parameters.description: IMPORTANT- TODO - currently you have to pass false for the swagger client - Have not found a way to force add a parameter. If `false` the coordinates in `point` and `snapped_waypoints` are returned as array using the order [lon,lat,elevation] for every point. If `true` the coordinates will be encoded as string leading to less bandwith usage. You'll need a special handling for the decoding of this string on the client-side. We provide open source code in [Java](https://github.com/graphhopper/graphhopper/blob/d70b63660ac5200b03c38ba3406b8f93976628a6/web/src/main/java/com/graphhopper/http/WebHelper.java#L43) and [JavaScript](https://github.com/graphhopper/graphhopper/blob/d70b63660ac5200b03c38ba3406b8f93976628a6/web/src/main/webapp/js/ghrequest.js#L139). It is especially important to use no 3rd party client if you set `elevation=true`!

parameters.name: calc_points
parameters.description: If the points for the route should be calculated at all printing out only distance and time.

parameters.name: point_hint
parameters.description: Optional parameter. Specifies a hint for each `point` parameter to prefer a certain street for the closest location lookup. E.g. if there is an address or house with two or more neighboring streets you can control for which street the closest location is looked up.

parameters.name: ch.disable
parameters.description: Use this parameter in combination with one or more parameters of this table

parameters.name: weighting
parameters.description: Which kind of 'best' route calculation you need. Other option is `shortest` (e.g. for `vehicle=foot` or `bike`), `short_fastest` if time and distance is expensive e.g. for `vehicle=truck`

parameters.name: edge_traversal
parameters.description: Use `true` if you want to consider turn restrictions for bike and motor vehicles. Keep in mind that the response time is roughly 2 times slower.

parameters.name: algorithm
parameters.description: The algorithm to calculate the route. Other options are `dijkstra`, `astar`, `astarbi`, `alternative_route` and `round_trip`

parameters.name: heading
parameters.description: Favour a heading direction for a certain point. Specify either one heading for the start point or as many as there are points. In this case headings are associated by their order to the specific points. Headings are given as north based clockwise angle between 0 and 360 degree. This parameter also influences the tour generated with `algorithm=round_trip` and force the initial direction.

parameters.name: heading_penalty
parameters.description: Penalty for omitting a specified heading. The penalty corresponds to the accepted time delay in seconds in comparison to the route without a heading.

parameters.name: pass_through
parameters.description: If `true` u-turns are avoided at via-points with regard to the `heading_penalty`.

parameters.name: details
parameters.description: List of additional trip attributes to be returned. Try some of the following: `average_speed`, `street_name`, `edge_id`, `time`, `distance`.

parameters.name: round_trip.distance
parameters.description: If `algorithm=round_trip` this parameter configures approximative length of the resulting round trip

parameters.name: round_trip.seed
parameters.description: If `algorithm=round_trip` this parameter introduces randomness if e.g. the first try wasn't good.

parameters.name: alternative_route.max_paths
parameters.description: If `algorithm=alternative_route` this parameter sets the number of maximum paths which should be calculated. Increasing can lead to worse alternatives.

parameters.name: alternative_route.max_weight_factor
parameters.description: If `algorithm=alternative_route` this parameter sets the factor by which the alternatives routes can be longer than the optimal route. Increasing can lead to worse alternatives.

parameters.name: alternative_route.max_share_factor
parameters.description: If `algorithm=alternative_route` this parameter specifies how much alternatives routes can have maximum in common with the optimal route. Increasing can lead to worse alternatives.

parameters.name: avoid
parameters.description: comma separate list to avoid certain roads. You can avoid motorway, ferry, tunnel or track

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: Get your key at graphhopper.com

get.description:
The GraphHopper Isochrone API allows calculating an isochrone of a locations means to calculate
'a line connecting points at which a vehicle arrives at the same time,'
see [Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isochrone_map).
It is also called **reachability** or **walkability**.

parameters.name: point
parameters.description: Specify the start coordinate

parameters.name: time_limit
parameters.description: Specify which time the vehicle should travel. In seconds.

parameters.name: distance_limit
parameters.description: Specify which distance the vehicle should travel. In meter.

parameters.name: vehicle
parameters.description: Possible vehicles are bike, car, foot and [more](https://graphhopper.com/api/1/docs/supported-vehicle-profiles/)

parameters.name: buckets
parameters.description: For how many sub intervals an additional polygon should be calculated.

parameters.name: reverse_flow
parameters.description: If `false` the flow goes from point to the polygon, if `true` the flow goes from the polygon "inside" to the point. Example usage for `false`: *How many potential customer can be reached within 30min travel time from your store* vs. `true`: *How many customers can reach your store within 30min travel time.*

parameters.name: weighting
parameters.description: Can be fastest or shortest

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: Get your key at graphhopper.com

get.description:
The Matrix API is part of the GraphHopper Directions API and with this API you can calculate many-to-many distances, times or routes a lot more efficient than calling the Routing API multiple times.
In the Routing API we support multiple points, so called 'via points', which results in one route being calculated. The Matrix API results in NxM routes or more precise NxM weights, distances or times being calculated but is a lot faster compared to NxM single requests. The most simple example is a tourist trying to decide which pizza is close to him instead of using beeline distance she can calculate a 1x4 matrix. Or a delivery service in the need of often big NxN matrices to solve vehicle routing problems. E.g. the GraphHopper Route Optimization API uses the Matrix API under the hood to achieve this.

parameters.name: point
parameters.description: Specifiy multiple points for which the weight-, route-, time- or distance-matrix should be calculated. In this case the starts are identical to the destinations. If there are N points, then NxN entries will be calculated. The order of the point parameter is important. Specify at least three points. Cannot be used together with from_point or to_point. Is a string with the format latitude,longitude.

parameters.name: from_point
parameters.description: The starting points for the routes. E.g. if you want to calculate the three routes A->1, A->2, A->3 then you have one from_point parameter and three to_point parameters. Is a string with the format latitude,longitude.

parameters.name: to_point
parameters.description: The destination points for the routes. Is a string with the format latitude,longitude.

parameters.name: point_hint
parameters.description: Optional parameter. Specifies a hint for each `point` parameter to prefer a certain street for the closest location lookup. E.g. if there is an address or house with two or more neighboring streets you can control for which street the closest location is looked up.

parameters.name: from_point_hint
parameters.description: For the from_point parameter. See point_hint

parameters.name: to_point_hint
parameters.description: For the to_point parameter. See point_hint

parameters.name: out_array
parameters.description: Specifies which arrays should be included in the response. Specify one or more of the following options 'weights', 'times', 'distances'. To specify more than one array use e.g. out_array=times&out_array=distances. The units of the entries of distances are meters, of times are seconds and of weights is arbitrary and it can differ for different vehicles or versions of this API.

parameters.name: vehicle
parameters.description: The vehicle for which the route should be calculated. Other vehicles are foot, small_truck etc

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: Get your key at graphhopper.com

post.description: The GET request has an URL length limitation, which hurts for many locations per request. In those cases use a HTTP POST request with JSON data as input. The only parameter in the URL will be the key which stays in the URL. Both request scenarios are identically except that all singular parameter names are named as their plural for a POST request.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: Get your key at graphhopper.com

get.description: This endpoint provides forward and reverse geocoding. For more details, review the official documentation at: https://graphhopper.com/api/1/docs/geocoding/

parameters.name: q
parameters.description: If you do forward geocoding, then this would be a textual description of the address you are looking for

parameters.name: locale
parameters.description: Display the search results for the specified locale. Currently French (fr), English (en), German (de) and Italian (it) are supported. If the locale wasn't found the default (en) is used.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: Specify the maximum number of returned results

parameters.name: reverse
parameters.description: Set to true to do a reverse Geocoding request, see point parameter

parameters.name: point
parameters.description: The location bias in the format 'latitude,longitude' e.g. point=45.93272,11.58803

parameters.name: provider
parameters.description: Can be either, default, nominatim, opencagedata

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: Get your key at graphhopper.com

post.summary: Solves vehicle routing and traveling salesman problems
post.description: This is the endpoint for solving vehicle routing or traveling salesman problems.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: Your API key

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: Request object that contains the problem to be solved

200.description: A jobId you can use to retrieve your solution from the server - see solution endpoint.

400.description: Error occurred when reading client request. Request is invalid.

get.summary: Return the solution associated to the jobId
get.description: This endpoint returns the solution of posted vehicle routing or traveling salesman problems. You can fetch it with the job_id, you have been sent.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: Your API key

parameters.name: jobId
parameters.description: Request solution with jobId

400.description: Error occurred on client side such as invalid input.

osm_type.description: N = node, R = relation, W = way

osm_key.description: The osm key of the result like `place` or `amenity`

points.description: Specifiy multiple points for which the weight-, route-, time- or distance-matrix should be calculated. In this case the starts are identical to the destinations. If there are N points, then NxN entries will be calculated. The order of the point parameter is important. Specify at least three points. Cannot be used together with from_point or to_point. Is a string with the format longitude,latitude.

from_points.description: The starting points for the routes. E.g. if you want to calculate the three routes A->1, A->2, A->3 then you have one from_point parameter and three to_point parameters. Is a string with the format longitude,latitude.

to_points.description: The destination points for the routes. Is a string with the format longitude,latitude.

point_hints.description: Optional parameter. Specifies a hint for each point in the `points` array to prefer a certain street for the closest location lookup. E.g. if there is an address or house with two or more neighboring streets you can control for which street the closest location is looked up.

from_point_hints.description: More information for the `from_points` array. See `point_hints`

to_point_hints.description: More information for the `to_points` array. See `point_hints`

out_arrays.description: Specifies which arrays should be included in the response. Specify one or more of the following options 'weights', 'times', 'distances'. To specify more than one array use e.g. out_array=times&out_array=distances. The units of the entries of distances are meters, of times are seconds and of weights is arbitrary and it can differ for different vehicles or versions of this API.

vehicle.description: The vehicle for which the route should be calculated. Other vehicles are foot, small_truck etc, see here for the details.

distance.description: The total distance of the route, in meter

time.description: The total time of the route, in ms

descend.description: The total descend (downhill) of the route, in meter

points_encoded.description: Is true if the points are encoded, if not paths[0].points contains the geo json of the path (then order is lon,lat,elevation), which is easier to handle but consumes more bandwidth compared to encoded version

bbox.description:
The bounding box of the route, format
minLon, minLat, maxLon, maxLat

ResponseInstructions.description: Contains information about the instructions for this route. The last instruction is always the Finish instruction and takes 0ms and 0meter. Keep in mind that instructions are currently under active development and can sometimes contain misleading information, so, make sure you always show an image of the map at the same time when navigating your users!

text.description: A description what the user has to do in order to follow the route. The language depends on the locale parameter.

street_name.description: The name of the street to turn onto in order to follow the route.

distance.description: The distance for this instruction, in meter

time.description: The duration for this instruction, in ms

interval.description: An array containing the first and the last index (relative to paths[0].points) of the points for this instruction. This is useful to know for which part of the route the instructions are valid.

sign.description:
A number which specifies the sign to show e.g. for right turn etc
TURN_SHARP_LEFT = -3
TURN_LEFT = -2
TURN_SLIGHT_LEFT = -1
CONTINUE_ON_STREET = 0
TURN_SLIGHT_RIGHT = 1
TURN_RIGHT = 2
TURN_SHARP_RIGHT = 3
FINISH = 4
VIA_REACHED = 5
USE_ROUNDABOUT = 6

annotation_text.description: optional - A text describing the instruction in more detail, e.g. like surface of the way, warnings or involved costs.

annotation_importance.description: optional - 0 stands for INFO, 1 for warning, 2 for costs, 3 for costs and warning

exit_number.description: optional - Only available for USE_ROUNDABOUT instructions. The count of exits at which the route leaves the roundabout.

turn_angle.description: optional - Only available for USE_ROUNDABOUT instructions. The radian of the route within the roundabout - 0<r<2*PI for clockwise and -2PI<r<0 for counterclockwise transit. Null if the direction of rotation is undefined.

job_id.description: unique id for your job/request with which you can fetch your solution

vehicles.description: Define one or more vehicles that can be employed to deliver items.

type_id.description: Unique identifier referring to the available vehicle types

return_to_depot.description: If it is false, the algorithm decides where to end the vehicle route. It ends in one of your customers' locations. The end is chosen such that it contributes to the overall objective function, e.g. min transport_time. If it is true, you can either specify a specific end location (which is then regarded as end depot) or you can leave it and the driver returns to its start location.

earliest_start.description: earliest start of vehicle at its start location

latest_end.description: latest end of vehicle at its end location

max_jobs.description: max number of jobs the vehicle can load

max_activities.description: max number of activities the vehicle can conduct

move_to_end_address.description: Indicates whether a vehicle should be moved even though it has not been assigned any jobs.

name.description: name of location, e.g. street name plus house number

street_hint.description: Optional parameter. Specifies a hint for each address to better snap the coordinates (lon,lat) to road network. E.g. if there is an address or house with two or more neighboring streets you can control for which street the closest location is looked up.

initial_driving_time.description: initial driving time, i.e. the time your driver has already spent for driving

type_id.description: Unique identifier for the vehicle type

service_time_factor.description: service time factor of vehicle type

cost_per_meter.description: cost parameter per distance unit, here meter is used

cost_per_second.description: cost parameter per time unit, here second is used

cost_per_activation.description: cost parameter vehicle activation, i.e. fixed costs per vehicle

consider_traffic.description: indicates whether historical traffic information should be considered

duration.description: duration of service, i.e. time in seconds the corresponding activity takes

preparation_time.description: preparation time of service, e.g. search for a parking space. it only falls due if the location of previous activity differs from this location

time_windows.description: array of time windows. currently, only a single time window is allowed

max_time_in_vehicle.description: max time service can stay in vehicle

priority.description: priority of service, i.e. 1 = high, 2 = normal, 3 = low. default is 2.

max_time_in_vehicle.description: max time shipment can stay in vehicle

duration.description: duration of stop, i.e. time in seconds the corresponding activity takes

preparation_time.description: preparation time of service, e.g. search for a parking space. it only falls due if the location of previous activity differs from this location

time_windows.description: array of time windows. currently, only a single time window is allowed

earliest.description: earliest start time of corresponding activity

latest.description: latest start time of corresponding activity

Configuration.description: Here you can specify general configurations of the API.

calc_points.description: It lets you specify whether the API should provide you with route geometries for vehicle routes or not. Thus, you do not need to do extra routing to get the polyline for each route.

consider_traffic.description: indicates whether historical traffic information should be considered

fail_fast.description: indicates whether matrix calculation should fail fast when points cannot be connected

type.description: type of objective function, i.e. min or min-max
type of cost matrix, currently default or google are supported

profile.description: vehicle profile or empty if catch all fallback

ids.description: An array of ids that should be related

items.description: id of services or special ids of shipments

groups.description: An array of groups that should be related

job_id.description: unique identify of job - which you get when posting your request to the large problem solver

status.description: indicates the current status of the job

processing_time.description: processing time in ms. if job is still waiting in queue, processing_time is 0

solution.description: the solution. only available if status field indicates finished

max_operation_time.description: operation time of the longest route in seconds

no_unassigned.description: number of jobs that could not be assigned to final solution

services.description: An array of ids of unassigned services

shipments.description: An array of ids of unassigned shipments

breaks.description: An array of ids of unassigned breaks

details.description: An array of details, i.e. reason for unassigned services or shipments

vehicle_id.description: id of vehicle that operates route

transport_time.description: transport time of route in seconds

completion_time.description: completion time of route in seconds

waiting_time.description: waiting time of route in seconds

service_duration.description: service duration of route in seconds

preparation_time.description: preparation time of route in seconds

id.description: id referring to the underlying service or shipment, i.e. the shipment or service this activity belongs to

arr_time.description: arrival time at this activity in seconds

end_time.description: end time of and thus departure time at this activity

end_date_time.description: end date time with offset like this 1970-01-01T01:00+01:00

arr_date_time.description: arrival date time with offset like this 1970-01-01T01:00+01:00

waiting_time.description: waiting time at this activity in seconds

preparation_time.description: preparation time at this activity in seconds

distance.description: cumulated distance from start to this activity in m

driving_time.description: driving time of driver in seconds

load_before.description: Array with size/capacity dimensions before this activity

load_after.description: Array with size/capacity dimensions after this activity
